title: Europe Migration Agreement Aims to Bolster Italy’s Pro-EU Government
text:
Italy’s new government in mid-September allowed the Ocean Viking rescue ship to bring to Italy 82 migrants rescued in the Mediterranean.

Germany and France have agreed to automatically take in some of the migrants rescued in the Mediterranean, in an effort to relieve pressure on Italy and establish a Europe-wide system to distribute migrants recovered at sea.

The plan marks an attempt by the European Union’s political establishment to shore up the new, pro-EU government in Rome, which is under pressure from the anti-immigration League party led by nativist firebrand Matteo Salvini.

Under the system, EU countries would volunteer to participate and take in asylum seekers who arrive at Italian or Maltese ports on rescue boats mostly operated by nongovernmental organizations.

Rescued migrants aboard the Ocean Viking on Sunday. Monday’s agreement would see migrants carried by such rescue ships distributed automatically around Europe. Photo: Renata Brito/Associated Press Over the past year, while Mr. Salvini was Interior Minister, Italy clashed repeatedly with other EU countries over NGO-run boats carrying migrants rescued at sea, which Mr. Salvini often banned from entering Italian ports. Mr. Salvini lost his office this month after a failed attempt to trigger snap elections, and is now in opposition—but opinion polls show his party is well-placed to win elections if Italy’s new, rickety coalition fails. “With Salvini out of power, European leaders are showing greater flexibility toward Italy to try to defuse the migration issue from the populists’ arsenal,” said Wolfango Piccoli, co-president of political-risk consulting firm Teneo. “It is certainly encouraging for the new government in Rome, but the new scheme is voluntary and temporary and it involves only a few countries.” Italy has for years complained that the EU has left it alone to deal with the problem of barely controlled immigration across the Mediterranean. The sea passage from Libya to Italy has been one of the main routes through which refugees from warzones and migrants seeking a better life have tried to reach Europe. The number of migrants landing in Italy has dropped sharply since 2017, but the issue continues to divide politics in Italy, as in much of the rest of the EU. Italy’s new, left-leaning governing coalition under Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte has vowed to work together with the EU on migration, rather than confront it as Mr. Salvini did. German Interior Minister Horst Seehofer said on Monday that he hoped 12-14 EU countries would participate in the distribution scheme for migrants rescued at sea. Mr. Seehofer said the migrants would be brought to ports in Italy, Malta and possibly France, where they would undergo security checks before being distributed within four weeks to participating EU countries. The recipient countries would process their asylum claims, and would have the right to withdraw from the pact if the arrangement, or the numbers of migrants, became disorderly, he said. “We want to save people from drowning: that’s our humane duty. But we also want order in the whole migration situation,” Mr. Seehofer said. Write to Giovanni Legorano at giovanni.legorano@wsj.com
